questions.question: A cylindrical tube opened at both the ends is made of iron sheet which is 2 cm thick. If the outer diameter is 16 cm and its length is 100 cm, find how many cubic centimeters of iron has been used in making the tube?
questions.solution:
Given:

  • Outer diameter = 16 cm $\Rightarrow$ Outer radius ($R$) = 8 cm
  • Thickness = 2 cm
  • Inner radius ($r$) = $R - \text{thickness} = 8 - 2 = 6$ cm
  • Length ($h$) = 100 cm

Step 1: Calculate the volume of iron used.

The volume of iron is the difference between the outer cylinder volume and the inner cylinder volume.

$$V = \pi R^2 h - \pi r^2 h = \pi h (R^2 - r^2)$$

$$V = \frac{22}{7} \times 100 \times (8^2 - 6^2)$$

$$V = \frac{2200}{7} \times (64 - 36)$$

$$V = \frac{2200}{7} \times 28$$

$$V = 2200 \times 4 = 8800 \text{ cm}^3$$

The volume of iron used is 8800 cm³.

questions.question: A semi-circular sheet of metal of diameter 28 cm is bent to form an open conical cup. Find the capacity of the cup.
questions.solution:
Given:

  • Diameter of semi-circular sheet = 28 cm $\Rightarrow$ Radius ($R_{sheet}$) = 14 cm

Step 1: Determine dimensions of the cone.

When the semi-circular sheet is bent into a cone:

  • Slant height of the cone ($l$) = Radius of the sheet = 14 cm
  • Circumference of the cone's base = Length of the semi-circular arc

$$2\pi r = \pi R_{sheet}$$

$$2\pi r = \pi (14) \Rightarrow 2r = 14 \Rightarrow r = 7 \text{ cm}$$

Step 2: Calculate the height of the cone.

$$h = \sqrt{l^2 - r^2} = \sqrt{14^2 - 7^2} = \sqrt{196 - 49} = \sqrt{147} = 7\sqrt{3} \text{ cm}$$

Step 3: Calculate the capacity (volume) of the cup.

$$V = \frac{1}{3}\pi r^2 h$$

$$V = \frac{1}{3} \times \frac{22}{7} \times 7^2 \times 7\sqrt{3}$$

$$V = \frac{1}{3} \times 22 \times 7 \times 7\sqrt{3} = \frac{1078\sqrt{3}}{3} \text{ cm}^3$$

Using $\sqrt{3} \approx 1.732$:

$$V \approx \frac{1078 \times 1.732}{3} \approx 622.38 \text{ cm}^3$$

questions.question: A cloth having an area of 165 m² is shaped into the form of a conical tent of radius 5 m. (i) How many students can sit in the tent if a student, on an average, occupies 5/7 m² on the ground? (ii) Find the volume of the cone.
questions.solution:
Given:

  • Area of cloth (Curved Surface Area) = 165 m²
  • Radius of tent ($r$) = 5 m

(i) Number of students:

Area occupied by one student = $5/7 \text{ m}^2$.

Total base area available = $\pi r^2 = \frac{22}{7} \times 5^2 = \frac{550}{7} \text{ m}^2$.

$$Number = \frac{\text{Base Area}}{\text{Area per student}} = \frac{550/7}{5/7} = \frac{550}{5} = 110$$

(ii) Volume of the cone:

First, find the slant height ($l$) from the CSA.

$$CSA = \pi r l = 165$$

$$\frac{22}{7} \times 5 \times l = 165$$

$$l = \frac{165 \times 7}{110} = \frac{3 \times 7}{2} = 10.5 \text{ m}$$

Now, find the height ($h$).

$$h = \sqrt{l^2 - r^2} = \sqrt{(10.5)^2 - 5^2} = \sqrt{110.25 - 25} = \sqrt{85.25} \approx 9.233 \text{ m}$$

$$V = \frac{1}{3}\pi r^2 h = \frac{1}{3} \times \frac{550}{7} \times 9.233 \approx 241.83 \text{ m}^3$$

questions.question: The water for a factory is stored in a hemispherical tank whose internal diameter is 14 m. The tank contains 50 kilolitres of water. Water is pumped into the tank to fill to its capacity. Calculate the volume of water pumped into the tank.
questions.solution:
Given:

  • Internal diameter = 14 m $\Rightarrow$ Radius ($r$) = 7 m
  • Current water volume = 50 kL = 50 m³ (since 1 kL = 1 m³)

Step 1: Calculate the total capacity of the tank.

$$V_{total} = \frac{2}{3}\pi r^3$$

$$V_{total} = \frac{2}{3} \times \frac{22}{7} \times 7^3 = \frac{44}{21} \times 343 = 44 \times \frac{49}{3} = \frac{2156}{3} \approx 718.67 \text{ m}^3$$

Step 2: Calculate the volume of water to be pumped.

$$V_{pumped} = V_{total} - V_{current}$$

$$V_{pumped} = 718.67 - 50 = 668.67 \text{ m}^3$$

questions.question: The volumes of the two spheres are in the ratio 64 : 27. Find the ratio of their surface areas.
questions.solution:
Given: Ratio of volumes $V_1 : V_2 = 64 : 27$.

Step 1: Find the ratio of radii.

$$\frac{V_1}{V_2} = \frac{\frac{4}{3}\pi r_1^3}{\frac{4}{3}\pi r_2^3} = \left(\frac{r_1}{r_2}\right)^3$$

$$\left(\frac{r_1}{r_2}\right)^3 = \frac{64}{27} \Rightarrow \frac{r_1}{r_2} = \sqrt[3]{\frac{64}{27}} = \frac{4}{3}$$

Step 2: Find the ratio of surface areas.

$$\frac{S_1}{S_2} = \frac{4\pi r_1^2}{4\pi r_2^2} = \left(\frac{r_1}{r_2}\right)^2$$

$$\frac{S_1}{S_2} = \left(\frac{4}{3}\right)^2 = \frac{16}{9}$$

The ratio of their surface areas is 16 : 9.

questions.question: A cube of side 4 cm contains a sphere touching its sides. Find the volume of the gap in between.
questions.solution:
Given: Cube side ($a$) = 4 cm.

Since the sphere touches the sides of the cube, the diameter of the sphere is equal to the side of the cube.

  • Sphere diameter = 4 cm $\Rightarrow$ Radius ($r$) = 2 cm

Step 1: Calculate the volume of the cube.

$$V_{cube} = a^3 = 4^3 = 64 \text{ cm}^3$$

Step 2: Calculate the volume of the sphere.

$$V_{sphere} = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3 = \frac{4}{3} \times \frac{22}{7} \times 2^3$$

$$V_{sphere} = \frac{4}{3} \times \frac{22}{7} \times 8 = \frac{704}{21} \approx 33.52 \text{ cm}^3$$

Step 3: Calculate the volume of the gap.

$$V_{gap} = V_{cube} - V_{sphere}$$

$$V_{gap} = 64 - 33.52 = 30.48 \text{ cm}^3$$

questions.question: A sphere and a right circular cylinder of the same radius have equal volumes. By what percentage does the diameter of the cylinder exceed its height?
questions.solution:
Given:

  • Radius of sphere = Radius of cylinder = $r$
  • $V_{sphere} = V_{cylinder}$

Step 1: Find the relationship between height and radius.

$$\frac{4}{3}\pi r^3 = \pi r^2 h$$

Dividing both sides by $\pi r^2$:

$$\frac{4}{3}r = h \Rightarrow h = \frac{4}{3}r$$

Step 2: Calculate the percentage difference.

Diameter of cylinder ($d$) = $2r$.

We need to find by what percentage $d$ exceeds $h$.

$$Percentage = \frac{d - h}{h} \times 100$$

$$Percentage = \frac{2r - \frac{4}{3}r}{\frac{4}{3}r} \times 100$$

$$Percentage = \frac{\frac{2}{3}r}{\frac{4}{3}r} \times 100 = \frac{2}{4} \times 100 = 50\%$$

questions.question: 30 circular plates, each of radius 14 cm and thickness 3 cm are placed one above the another to form a cylindrical solid. Find: (i) the total surface area (ii) volume of the cylinder so formed.
questions.solution:
Given:

  • Number of plates = 30
  • Radius ($r$) = 14 cm
  • Thickness of one plate = 3 cm

Step 1: Determine dimensions of the resulting cylinder.

  • Radius ($R$) = 14 cm
  • Height ($H$) = $30 \times 3 = 90$ cm

(i) Total Surface Area:

$$TSA = 2\pi R (R + H)$$

$$TSA = 2 \times \frac{22}{7} \times 14 (14 + 90)$$

$$TSA = 2 \times 22 \times 2 \times 104 = 88 \times 104 = 9152 \text{ cm}^2$$

(ii) Volume:

$$V = \pi R^2 H$$

$$V = \frac{22}{7} \times 14^2 \times 90$$

$$V = \frac{22}{7} \times 196 \times 90 = 22 \times 28 \times 90 = 55440 \text{ cm}^3$$
